instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
Checked if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present and it is. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is also present
I reflowed the SMC, no change

I'm guessing this is definitely an SMC replacement isnt it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: probably important to mention that the board is pristine. No sign of liquid damage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> exact voltage?
Is it stable?
Also check if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is stable high.
Did you try known good DCIN board?

Try to start in SMC bypass mode.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
revisiting this now, just received donor boards for it jsut in case. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.56v and stable
SMC reset is 3.37v stable
Does nothing on SMC bypass, no fan spin. 
checked with two other DC in boards as well
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> available 


I replaced ISL and now I always get green light, no more fading

Could it be a fake charger that caused this? perhaps sending 18v somewhere it shouldnt have?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
You should get orange light, even without battery.
Is it original Magsafe 2 60/85W?

What about <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
sorry i totally meant orange light. It's got orange light. yes to the magsafe. 

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: Ok so triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> drops the voltage to 0.4 or even less initially. however it doesn't do it again until i have the machine off the charger for a bit and then start again. Bascially only does it once after plugging in charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: actually im wrong, it does it repeatedly, it's just hard to catch. drops down to almost 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: hmmmm now <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is stuck on 1v continiously

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: after triggering SMC it's back to 3v3 on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>. and drops every time i trigger smc like clockwork

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: sometimes <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> gets stuck low continiously

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts, then check for pulse (at same time) at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0</SIGNAL> starts low, when triggered goes 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL> starts low, when triggered goes 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> starts low, when triggered goes over 2v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL> starts low, when triggered goes over to 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
Then all S3/0 voltages should pulse too, check that.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses?
Did you try SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses yes
SMC bypass does nothing. it's as if i'm not even doing it. Usually the light stays off when holding down power button but the light turns on as if i wasnt pressing it.

Also jsut replaced the SMC (i was feeling lucky) and has the exact same symtoms as before
tested S3 and s0 lines and all pulse too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
Did you try BIOS?
Check if pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulse too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulse too
Can i try a new bios without transferring programming just to see if it works? I don't curtrently have a programmer

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message:
Be sure is known good working BIOS.
No need to fix it, as is just for test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: BIOS tested and no difference. is there anything else I can do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: Just checking if there's anything else I could test on this or is this a rabbit hole? thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> temporary green light then fades. no fan spin
threads.message: Check for short, or very low value to ground, on audio filter caps from 5V power rail.
